seo.title: Asylia.io – Bitcoin Fortress
seo.description: Asylia.io is a Bitcoin fortress built on multisignature, giving users full control over their keys while offering a reliable co-signer for critical situations. The Collaborative Partial Custody (CPC) model minimizes trust in third parties, fees are voluntary, and open-source code ensures auditability.

your_keys_your_kingdom: Your Keys. Your Bitcoin. Your Kingdom.
introMessage: “Bitcoin fortress, where sovereignty meets security. Protect your digital wealth with proven multisignature technology. Because true ownership means responsibility — today and for generations to come.”

wp0.title: Summary
wp0.p1: Asylia.io is a Bitcoin fortress built on multisignature, giving users full control over their keys while offering a reliable co-signer in critical situations. The Collaborative Partial Custody (CPC) model minimizes trust in third parties, fees are voluntary, and the open-source code ensures auditability.

wp1.title: 1. Introduction: The Bitcoin Fortress
wp1.p1: We live in an era where privacy, sovereignty, and security are not just slogans but essential pillars of financial freedom and stability. Asylia.io represents a Bitcoin fortress built with one clear purpose: to secure your Bitcoin using proven multisignature technology — transactions requiring multiple independent signatures.

wp2.title: 2. Why Asylia.io?
wp2.p1: The name “Asylia” comes from Greek and means “territorial inviolability,” symbolizing a secure place where your digital assets are protected from any unauthorized interference. The .io domain refers to input‑output, emphasizing reliability, transparency, and uninterrupted access to your Bitcoin.

list1.title: What we believe in
list1.point_1: Sovereignty and self-reliance – the keys are always in your hands.
list1.point_3: Interoperability – we adhere to Bitcoin standards.
list1.point_4: Quality and integrity – we do things right, even when no one is watching.

list2.title: What we will never compromise on:
list2.point_2: Speed at the cost of quality.

list1.title: 4.1 Multisignature Model
list1.point_3: Asylia holds only a minority of keys (never a quorum)

list2.title: 4.2 Keys & Hardware
list2.point_2: Offline cold storage for Asylia keys

list3.title: 4.3 Transaction Flow
list3.point_3: P2SH‑P2WSH today, Taproot in the roadmap

list4.title: 4.4 Recovery Modes
list4.point_1: Non‑KYC recovery: social recovery, backup signatures, timelocks

wp5.title: 5. Who is Asylia.io for?
wp5.point_1: Bitcoin holders with a long-term vision

wp6.title: 6. Business Model & Fees
wp6.p1: Asylia.io operates without entry fees or recurring monthly payments. Users can voluntarily add support in the form of a Bitcoin transaction output during sending.

row2.td2: 2.1% of the transferred amount<sup>1</sup> (output in PSBT)

poc.title: Proof‑of‑Concept (PoC) ⚠
poc.text: Functional but non-production code is available at poc.asylia.io and GitHub repository Asylia/poc. DO NOT USE with real funds.

legal.title: Legal Framework
legal.point2: GDPR: IP logs & timestamps stored for 30 days, pseudonymized

wp7.title: 7. Future Extensions & Roadmap
wp7.point2: Code audit external security audit + penetration testing
wp7.point3: Mobile app for iOS & Android, Bluetooth + NFC PSBT signing
wp7.point4: Private instance guide Docker / Ansible, CLI API
wp7.next: Further R&D: Taproot migration, Web3 redundancy, zero‑knowledge proof of reserves.

wp8.title: 8. Risk Analysis (Threat Model)
wp8.point1: Theft of < quorum of keys: n‑of‑T multisig – minority key is not enough
wp8.point2: Insider at Asylia: open-source, code-review, HSM – insider holds only a minority key
wp8.point3: Supply-chain attack (firmware): verified HW wallet sources, checksum verification
wp8.point4: Human factor / phishing: educational materials, FIDO2‑U2F login, two‑man recovery
wp8.point5: Infrastructure outage: offline PSBT, fallback Web3 node
wp8.point6: Regulatory / KYC pressure: optional KYC, PDF backup of signing policies

wp9.title: 9. Call for Collaboration
wp9.point1: Consultants in Bitcoin, multisig, and BIP standards
wp9.point5: Sponsors supporting a secure Bitcoin ecosystem

wp10.title: 10. Our Promises
wp10.point1: Independence – free migration to another platform

wp11.title: 11. Disclaimer
wp11.p1: Asylia.io provides tools to secure your Bitcoin, but it does not take responsibility for the loss of private keys or for damages caused by improper use of the platform. The user is fully responsible for managing their assets.

wp12.title: 12. Conclusion: The Future is Secure
wp12.p1: Just as fortresses once protected cities from invasions, Asylia protects your digital wealth from the risks of the modern age.
wp12.q1:
“Fiat castrum securitatis, et portae fluctuum non praevalebunt.”
(Let the fortress of security arise, and the gates of storms shall not prevail against it.)
wp12.q2: “Asylia does not exist to grow fast. Asylia exists to endure.”

team.title: Our Team.
team.q1: “A work is only as strong as its creators.”

member1.p:
The founder, author, and core developer of the Asylia.io project is a long-standing technology professional with over a decade of experience in developing web and mobile applications, security solutions, and decentralized technologies.
Driven by a personal conviction in the importance of sovereignty, privacy, and security, he combined technological expertise with a deep understanding of Bitcoin’s principles into a project aimed at delivering a truly secure and independent custody solution.
Asylia was born out of a simple but firm belief:
member1.p2: The Asylia.io project is not a marketing experiment, but a long-term commitment to building a more secure Bitcoin ecosystem, founded on honesty, traditional values, and technical precision.
